description.title: COMBINED EPI + RESOURCES MODEL STRUCTURE
paragraphs: 1. The Epidemiological component (epi) models the transmission dynamics of an acute infectious disease such as avian influenza by categorising individuals according to their infectious status (Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Recovered). This structure allows users to estimate the proportion of people infected and, more importantly, test the likely effect of public policies aimed at controlling the spread of the disease. This component also provides the signal for the Hospital module, driving the demand for hospital resources.

2. The Hospital module models the movement of patients through the hospital system and focuses on ward beds and ICU beds. Patient pathways - from waiting for a ward or ICU bed, to admission to a ward or ICU (or to overflows), to occupying a ward or ICU bed, to patient discharges or deaths - are all governed over time by adjustable model parameters, e.g. recovery time, mortality rate and average length of stay in ICU. The number of patients in the various stages of this simulated process (e.g. waiting for a bed or in a ward bed) each provide a signal for the Hospital resources module, where associated resource needs and current usage will be calculated.

3. The Hospital Resources module calculates the need for other resources for patients who need or who occupy a ward bed or an ICU bed. Ward patients each need not only a physical bed but a share of a nurse's time. ICU patients need a physical ICU bed, a share of an ICU nurse's time, and many will also require a ventilator. All nurses require PPE in order to work safely with patients. All these resources are limited, and availability and gaps are calculated. This module also calculates the number of staffed ward beds and staffed, equipped ICU beds available, and these provide signals back to the Hospital module, where they are used to limit admission flows into ward beds and ICU beds.
The above modules are all contained within one Stella Architect model (.stmx) file.

parameters.name: Population Size
parameters.description: Population size

parameters.name: Ward Beds per 1K
parameters.description: Hospital ward beds per 1000 population, for all purposes.

parameters.name: ICU Beds per 100K
parameters.description: ICU beds per 100 thousand population, for all purposes.

parameters.name: Ward Nurses per 1K
parameters.description: General ward nurses per 1000 population.

parameters.name: ICU Nurses per 100K
parameters.description: ICU nurses per 1000 population.

parameters.name: Ventilators per 100K
parameters.description: Mechanical ventilators per 100 thousand population

parameters.name: Age Specific Contact Rates
parameters.description: Average number of daily contacts per person in peace time

parameters.name: Physicians per 100K
parameters.description: Hospital physicians per 100,000 population

parameters.name: Normal morgue capacity per 100K
parameters.description: Total number of hospital mortuary spaces per 100,000 population in normal (peace-time) conditions

parameters.name: Normal target PPE stock level per 1K
parameters.description: Target PPE stock level per 1K population for all purposes. Hospitals will aim to keep stocks at this target level, ordering more when usage rates are higher.

parameters.name: Vaccines
parameters.description: Vaccine switch.

parameters.name: Vaccine efficacy
parameters.description: Vaccine efficacy against transmission. This parameter denotes the probability that a person becomes immune to the disease after receiving the vaccine.

parameters.name: Vaccine available from (day)
parameters.description: Day at which vaccines become available for starting the vaccination campaign.

parameters.name: Initial vaccination capacity
parameters.description: Vaccination capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system can vaccinate people in a day. This parameter corresponds this stock's initial value. Furthermore, these rates are expressed per 1000 population.

parameters.name: Vaccination capacity growth rate
parameters.description: Vaccination capacity is modelled as a stock whose change over time is defined by the logistic growth structure. This structure produces S-shaped behaviour over time. Specifically, this parameter represents the rate at which the stock grows should there were no constraints. In the context of this model, this parameter can be viewed as the velocity at which the public health system scales up vaccination capacity. This parameter is expressed as a percentage.

parameters.name: Long-term vaccination capacity
parameters.description: Vaccination capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system can vaccinate people in a day. This parameter denotes the maximum rate that the public health system can achieve. This value is expressed per 1000 population.

parameters.name: Mobility restriction severity
parameters.description: This parameter represents the stringency of social distancing measures. In the model, this parameter has an inversely proportional effect on the average number of contacts that people have per day. The higher the severity, the lower the number of contacts.

parameters.name: Mobility restriction start day
parameters.description: Time at which mobility restrictions start.

parameters.name: Maximum duration (days)
parameters.description: Maximum number of days that public funds can support the social distance measures at maximum severity (full lockdown).

parameters.name: School closures
parameters.description: School closures switch.

parameters.name: Start school closures (day)
parameters.description: Day at which school & educational settings are closed.

parameters.name: Duration school closures (days)
parameters.description: This parameter indicates for how many days schools & education settings will be closed.

parameters.name: Testing
parameters.description: Testing switch.

parameters.name: Testing available from (day)
parameters.description: Day at which testing starts.

parameters.name: Initial testing capacity
parameters.description: Testing capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system can confirm a test result in a day. This parameter corresponds to this stock's initial value. Furthermore, these rates are expressed per 10000 population.

parameters.name: Testing capacity growth rate
parameters.description: Testing capacity is modelled as a stock whose change over time is defined by the logistic growth structure. This structure produces S-shaped behaviour over time. Specifically, this parameter represents the rate at which the stock grows should there were no constraints. In the context of this model, this parameter can be viewed as the velocity at which the public health system scales up testing capacity. This parameter is expressed as a percentage.

parameters.name: Long-term testing capacity
parameters.description: Testing capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system confirm test results in a day. This parameter denotes the maximum rate that the public health system can achieve. This value is expressed per 10000 population.

parameters.name: Isolation
parameters.description: Isolation switch.

parameters.name: Isolation policy from (day)
parameters.description: Date at which infected individuals with a confirmed test abide policy recommendation of self-isolation.

parameters.name: Isolation compliance
parameters.description: Isolation compliance.

parameters.name: Contact tracing
parameters.description: Contact tracing switch

parameters.name: Contact tracing available from (day)
parameters.description: Day at which contact tracing starts.

parameters.name: Quarantine compliance
parameters.description: This parameter indicates the probability that individual will abide public heath recommendations to quarantine after being identified as a close contact. In the model, this parameter has an inversely proportional effect on the effective contact rate of quarantined individuals. The higher the compliance, the lower the contact rate.

parameters.name: Initial contact tracing capacity
parameters.description: Contact tracing capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system can trace people in a day. This parameter corresponds to this stock's initial value. Furthermore, these rates are expressed per 100000 population.

parameters.name: Contact tracing capacity growth rate
parameters.description: Contact tracing capacity is modelled as a stock whose change over time is defined by the logistic growth structure. This structure produces S-shaped behaviour over time. Specifically, this parameter represents the rate at which the stock grows should there were no constraints. In the context of this model, this parameter can be viewed as the velocity at which the public health system scales up contact tracing capacity. This parameter is expressed as a percentage.

parameters.name: Long-term contact tracing capacity
parameters.description: Contact tracing capacity is modelled as a stock that grows over time. The values of this stock represent the rate at which the public health system can contact trace people in a day. This parameter denotes the maximum rate that the public health system can achieve. This value is expressed per 100000 population.

parameters.name: Mask wearing
parameters.description: Mask-wearing switch.

parameters.name: Mask wearing from (day)
parameters.description: Day at which individuals start wearing masks.

parameters.name: Mask wearing effect
parameters.description: This policy parameter represents the efficacy of introducing a mask-wearing policy in the population. In this context, efficacy refers to the reduction in the probability of infection after contact between two individuals. This parameter takes values between 0 and 1 (or 0% and 100%).

parameters.name: Probability of infection
parameters.description: This parameter represents the probability of infection after a contact between a susceptible and clinical infectious individuals. This parameter can take values between 0 and 1 inclusive, and also corresponds to the prob_inf parameter of the R0 API.

parameters.name: Hospitalisation fraction
parameters.description: Proportion of infected people, whether detected or undetected, who are hospitalised

parameters.name: Fraction ICU
parameters.description: Fraction of patients admitted to hospital who require ICU on admission

parameters.name: Fraction ward To ICU
parameters.description: Fraction of patients in wards who later require ICU

parameters.name: Delay before hospitalisation (days)
parameters.description: The average delay between developing symptoms and hospitalisation

parameters.name: Admission delay
parameters.description: Wait time for patients admitted to hospital to obtain a ward bed

parameters.name: ICU admission delay
parameters.description: Average patient wait time for ICU bed

parameters.name: LOS ward
parameters.description: Average length of stay in ward bed

parameters.name: LOS ICU
parameters.description: Average length of stay in ICU bed

parameters.name: LOS ward before ICU
parameters.description: Average length of stay of patients in ward who go on to require transfer to ICU

parameters.name: LOS denied ICU
parameters.description: Average length of stay of patients in ICU Overflow (time to die or survive) (model assumption)

parameters.name: LOS ward deaths
parameters.description: Average length of stay of patients who die in ward beds

parameters.name: LOS ICU deaths
parameters.description: Average length of stay in ICU of patients who die

parameters.name: LOS morgue
parameters.description: Average length of stay of a body in hospital morgue

parameters.name: LOS temporary morgue
parameters.description: Average length of stay of a body in a temporary morgue

parameters.name: Ward fatality rate
parameters.description: Proportion of ward patients who die

parameters.name: ICU fatality rate
parameters.description: Proportion of ICU patients who die

parameters.name: Denied ICU fatality rate
parameters.description: Proportion of patients unable to access ICU who die

parameters.name: Fraction ward to ICU antivirals
parameters.description: The expected reduction in the fraction of patients in wards who later require ICU, if they were treated with antivirals (-0.2 means 20% reduction)

parameters.name: LOS ward antivirals
parameters.description: The expected reduction in average length of stay in ward bed for ward patients given timely antiviral treatment (-0.2 means 20% reduction)

parameters.name: Ward fatality rate antivirals
parameters.description: The expected reduction in the proportion of ward patients who die, if they are given timely antiviral treatment (-0.2 means 20% reduction)

parameters.name: LOS ICU vaccines
parameters.description: The expected reduction in average length of stay in ICU bed for ICU patients given vaccine for earlier strains (-0.2 means 20% reduction)

parameters.name: ICU fatality rate vaccines
parameters.description: The expected reduction in the proportion of ICU patients who die, if they are given existing vaccines for earlier strains (-0.2 means 20% reduction)

parameters.name: Proportion of beds available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of hospital beds made available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of ICU beds available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of ICU beds made available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of nurses available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of nurses available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of ICU nurses available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of ICU nurses available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of physicians available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of physicians available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of ventilators available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of ventilators made available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of PPE available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of PPE made available for care of pandemic patients

parameters.name: Proportion of morgue capacity available for pandemic
parameters.description: Proportion of morgue spaces made available for deceased pandemic patients

parameters.name: Nurses per bed
parameters.description: Normal number of nurses required per patient in a ward bed

parameters.name: ICU nurses per bed
parameters.description: Normal number of ICU nurses per patient in an ICU bed

parameters.name: Fraction ICU patients requiring ventilator
parameters.description: The fraction of ICU patients that require a ventilator

parameters.name: Fraction ward patients requiring high flow nasal oxygen
parameters.description: Proportion of ward patients needing high flow nasal oxygen

parameters.name: Fraction ward patients requiring low flow nasal oxygen
parameters.description: Proportion of ward patients needing low flow nasal oxygen

parameters.name: PPE per staff per day (PPE sets)
parameters.description: PPE sets used per staff member per day (or shift)

parameters.name: Average low flow oxygen rate (litres/min)
parameters.description: Average low flow oxygen rate (litres/min)

parameters.name: Average high flow oxygen rate (litres/min)
parameters.description: Average high flow oxygen rate (litres/min)

parameters.name: Average oxygen rate from ventilator (litres/min)
parameters.description: Average oxygen rate from ventilator (litres/min)

parameters.name: PPE days supply in target stock
parameters.description: The desired number of days of supply of PPE to keep in stock

parameters.name: PPE acquisition lag (days)
parameters.description: Average delay between ordering PPE and PPE delivery

parameters.name: Antiviral capacity
parameters.subcategory: Therapeutic capacity (proportion of patients that can be treated, 0 to 1)
parameters.description: Capacity of therapeutic antiviral treatment, between zero and 1. Zero means none available, 1 means available to all ward patients (and assumes given to all)

parameters.name: Previous strain vaccine capacity
parameters.subcategory: Therapeutic capacity (proportion of patients that can be treated, 0 to 1)
parameters.description: Capacity of vaccines for previous strains that can help current patients, between zero and 1. Zero means none available, 1 means available to all ICU patients (and assumes given to all)

parameters.name: Threshold number of beds blocked by deceased (persons)
parameters.description: The number of hospital beds blocked by deceased patients that triggers emergency procedures such as army personnel moving bodies to temporary morgues

parameters.name: Reduce ICU nurse to patient ratio
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 1: activate when ICU nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Whether to reduce the ICU nurse-to-patient ratio (for all patients) when ICU nurses are lacking

parameters.name: Reduced ICU nurses per bed
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 1: activate when ICU nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Number of ICU nurses required per patient/bed when availability of ICU nurses is low, if surge strategy enabled

parameters.name: Nurse burnout rate
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 1: activate when ICU nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Proportion of all nurses who become absent due to stress when workload is increased to meet higher demand

parameters.name: Reduce nurse to patient ratio
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 2: activate when ward nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Whether to enable surge strategy of reducing the ward nurse-to-patient ratio (for all patients) when ward nurses are lacking

parameters.name: Reduced nurses per bed
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 2: activate when ward nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Number of nurses required per patient/bed when availability of nurses is low, if surge strategy enabled

parameters.name: Nurse burnout rate
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 2: activate when ward nurse capacity is low
parameters.description: Proportion of all nurses who become absent due to stress when workload is increased to meet staff shortages

parameters.name: Reduce PPE per shift
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 3: activate when PPE supplies run low
parameters.description: Whether to reduce number of PPE sets used per shift when PPE is in short supply

parameters.name: Reduced PPE per staff per day
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 3: activate when PPE supplies run low
parameters.description: PPE sets used per staff member per day (or shift) in times of low availability of PPE, if surge strategy is enabled

parameters.name: Increased risk to staff if PPE use reduced
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 3: activate when PPE supplies run low
parameters.description: Increased risk to staff if surge strategy to reduce PPE usage rates is enabled

parameters.name: Simulate interruption in PPE supply
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 3: activate when PPE supplies run low
parameters.description: Whether to model an interruption in the supply of PPE during the peak of the pandemic

parameters.name: Increase bed capacity
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 4: activate when physical ward bed capacity is low
parameters.description: Whether to increase bed capacity when no beds are available, by diverting from non-pandemic use

parameters.name: Surge capacity bed increase
parameters.subcategory: Strategy 4: activate when physical ward bed capacity is low
parameters.description: Proportion of all beds to make available when surge capacity is enabled and beds are all occupied

parameters.name: Simulate staff absenteeism
parameters.description: Whether to include staff absenteeism in the model (i.e. factor in pandemic infections and burnout in staff leading to absence)

parameters.name: Simulate interruption in PPE supply
parameters.description: Whether to model an interruption in the supply of PPE during the peak of the pandemic

parameters.name: Initial number of infected people
parameters.description: Number of infected people at the start of the pandemic.
